This Rechargeable Lighter Helped Me Actually Ditch Butane  | Bon Appétit

However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.This is Highly Recommend, a column dedicated to what people in the food industry are obsessed with eating, drinking, and buying right now. A rechargeable lighter, in this case.After a road trip gone right last summer, I’ve spent most of the year far from my Silicon Valley home, reveling in the wilds of Montana. Big Sky Country is transformationally beautiful. Its sweeping fields, cathedral-like mountain ranges, and babbling cricks are clean, clear, and threatened only by an influx of out-of-staters moving here, like me. Fueled by natural awe (and an admitted tinge of tourist guilt), I’ve been eager to live here as sustainably as possible. When I learned that 350 million disposable butane lighters—like the ones I was using to ignite my fireplace on frosty mornings—are thrown away in the United States every year, I was keen to do something about it. Enter scene: this ultra-sustainable and tech-savvy USB Rechargeable Lighter from the USB Lighter Company.Photography by Isa Zapata.  Prop Styling by Paige HicksUSB Rechargeable Lighter$32 at Food52$30 at The GrommetThe svelte lighter arrived in zero-waste packaging that’s been approved by the nonprofit Forest Stewardship Council (“Forests for All Forever,” baby). It’s now become a Why hadn’t I thought of this? home addition. I use it to fire the char-grill to crackle up home-raised rib eyes and to light my Boy Smells Cowboy Kush candle for journaling and meditation sessions. And unlike the case with matches, I can execute the Operation-like precision tasks required to light a dead pilot light or tea candles without ending up with torched fingertips, sooty smoke streaks, or a visit from the fire department.The sustainable part is right in its name—the USB Rechargeable Lighter plugs into a computer or any other electrical outlet. It’s also butane-free and gas appliance-safe. It holds a whopping 300 uses per charge, leveraging tesla coil technology (a sweet reminder of the motherland), and mine has been going strong since its last charge three months ago. Plus, it comes in cherry reds, sunny yellows, metallics, and gem tones. I’ll need my rose-gold one to spark joy as the winter cold hits.And it’s so, so easy to use. Although I do not have a firm grasp on the physics of combustion, I can tell you that the lighter’s two prongs conduct a neon arc of electricity that bursts into fire. After lighting what I need to (ideally, this camping-friendly Snow Peak GigaPower Torch for home-made wagyu nigiri), I can glide the prongs safely back into the lighter’s neck for storage, which automatically disables the ignition button. Smart.Using this sustainable lighter is a very small ritual, but it feels like an appropriate way to thank the breathtaking state of Montana—the place that has ignited so elegantly my love for the great outdoors.
